etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Noah Biggs (fl. 1651), medical practitioner and social reformer. From post-classical Latin empyreumaticus from ancient Greek ἐμπυρευματ-, ἐμπύρευμα + classical Latin -icus

definitions: Relating to or having the quality of empyreuma; tasting or smelling of charred organic matter.
